{"step_by_step_thinking": "Fordyce's spots are small, raised, pale or white spots that may appear on the lips, inside of the cheeks, or on the genitalia. They are not associated with any symptoms and are considered a normal variation of the anatomy. Fordyce's spots are actually ectopic sebaceous glands, which means they are oil glands that are located in an abnormal location. They are not fat tissue embedded in buccal mucosa (option A) or red spots (option B). Fordyce's spots are typically present on the cheek mucosa lateral to the angle of the mouth (option C). Therefore, the correct answer is D. All of the above.", "answer_choice": "D"}
